awd_titl_txt: 2017 National Workshop on Developing a Research Agenda for Connected Rural Communities (CRC17)
awd_abstract_narration:
Driven by the challenges as well as opportunities for high-impact research to advance the quality of life in small, remote, and rural communities, the University of Virginia will convene a workshop to explore challenges and research opportunities, to facilitate collaborations, and ultimately, to define a connected rural communities research agenda. Specifically, the research exploration will be discussed through the lens of how technology, communications, and networking can advance polycentric development. The two-day workshop will bring together researchers, practitioners, nonprofit organizations, industry partners, government representatives, and community stakeholders in the domain of Smart and Connected Communities (S&CC) with representation from around the United States (U.S.).  

Successful implementation of this workshop will result in a connected rural communities research agenda detailing new opportunities for research with long-term impact and near-term outcomes. Participants will engage in discussions to characterize and design future S&CC testbeds together with communities themselves, to support the interative S&CC research cycle necessary for transformative innovations that benefit communities. The workshop will explore a diversity of domains (e.g., mobility, economic development, education, and public and telehealth) and their interconnectivity. In order to assure representation of multiple perspectives, the workshop organizers will prioritize participation of minority and underrepresented community members, and those that can speak from experience on the relevant challenges and opportunities in small, remote, and rural communities around the U.S. It is anticipated that half of the participants will be from outside the academic community. Participation of early-career researchers and practitioners are especially emphasized to catalyze new partnerships and research communities in this critical domain.

por.por_cntn:
The University of Virginia (UVA) convened a national workshop on September 7-8th, 2017 in Charlottesville, Virginia to examine challenges and opportunities for high-impact technology research to advance quality of life in small, remote, and rural communities.  The meeting was attended by approximately 90 participants representing different academia disciplines, industry sectors, government agencies, and community organizations.  Participants comprised researchers, practitioners, policy makers, and members of the community. Participants agreed that in order for Smart Cities research and development to be adopted and have an impact in under-connected communities, several key factors must be taken into consideration, including: innovating around the lack of infrastructure, preserving community identity and culture, and overcoming the economy-of-scale bottleneck. Each of these issues were discussed in-depth. Some of the main observations for these topics are as follows.  It was agreed that the lack of infrastructure, especially for communication and networking, is a front and center issue in under-connected rural communities.  Researchers are encouraged to pursue practical as well as bold and creative technical approaches to deliver resources and services instead of waiting for infrastructure to be available.  Infrastructure development must also couple with capacity building to enable effective data management and cyber security.  Quality of service (e.g., accessibility, performance, and cost) must be considered as research drivers and not an afterthought in the deployment phase.  Applications taking advantage of new infrastructure must be developed in conjunction with the community to support adoption and scale up.  Social perspectives are critical to ascertain and maintain community culture, values, and identity.  New socio-technical metrics must be developed to assess the overall community health and impact of R&D efforts. Critical public services in under-connected communities such as emergency response and public safety are further challenged by the lack of infrastructure and burdened by the economy-of-scale.   Access to quality healthcare is also front and center in advancing quality of life in under-connected communities.  A final report detailing these and many of the underlying research issues was produced and made available to the public.

A second workshop was also created and run to address a related and pressing issue. Cyber physical systems research is critical to achieving smart cities and associated support for rural communities. It is important to support new PhDs in pursuit of academic careers, especially underrepresented minorities. To this end a Rising Stars workshop was created and run in May 2022 to identify top PhD students and instruct them on many topics to help them obtain academic positions and be successful in those positions. Topics in the workshop included the job search process and navigating the early stages of academia. Overall, there were 124 applicants and 33 were chosen as Rising Stars. These Rising Stars represented 22 Universities and 16 were underrepresented minorities. It is hoped to make this an annual workshop.
